2275        [1] Landsgesell, J., Hebbeker, P., Rud, O., Lunkad, R., Košovan, P., & Holm, C. (2020). Grand-reaction method for simulations of ionization equilibria coupled to ion partitioning. Macromolecules, 53(8), 3007-3020.
2276
2277        Args:
2278            pH_res ('float): pH-value in the reservoir.
2279            c_salt_res ('float'): Concentration of monovalent salt (e.g. NaCl) in the reservoir.
2280            proton_name ('str'): Name of the proton (H+) particle.
2281            hydroxide_name ('str'): Name of the hydroxide (OH-) particle.
2282            salt_cation_name ('str'): Name of the salt cation (e.g. Na+) particle.
2283            salt_anion_name ('str'): Name of the salt anion (e.g. Cl-) particle.
2284            SEED ('int'): Seed for the random number generator.
2285            activity_coefficient ('callable', optional): A function that calculates the activity coefficient of an ion pair as a function of the ionic strength.
2286            exclusion_range(`float`, optional): For distances shorter than this value, no particles will be inserted.
2287            pka_set(`dict`,optional): Desired pka_set, pka_set(`dict`): {"name" : {"pka_value": pka, "acidity": acidity}}. Defaults to None.
2288            use_exclusion_radius_per_type(`bool`,optional): Controls if one exclusion_radius for each espresso_type is used. Defaults to `False`.
2289
2290        Returns:
2291            RE (`obj`): Instance of a reaction_ensemble.ReactionEnsemble object from the espressomd library.
2292            sucessful_reactions_labels(`lst`): Labels of the reactions set up by pyMBE.
2293            ionic_strength_res ('float'): Ionic strength of the reservoir (useful for calculating partition coefficients).
2294        """
2295        from espressomd import reaction_methods
2296        if exclusion_range is None:
2297            exclusion_range = max(self.get_radius_map().values())*2.0
2298        if pka_set is None:
2299            pka_set=self.get_pka_set()    
2300        self.check_pka_set(pka_set=pka_set)
2301        if use_exclusion_radius_per_type:
2302            exclusion_radius_per_type = self.get_radius_map()
2303        else:
2304            exclusion_radius_per_type = {}
2305        
2306        #If no function for the activity coefficient is provided, the ideal case is assumed.
2307        if activity_coefficient is None:
2308            activity_coefficient = lambda x: 1.0
2309        
2310        RE = reaction_methods.ReactionEnsemble(kT=self.kT.to('reduced_energy').magnitude,
2311                                                    exclusion_range=exclusion_range.magnitude, 
2312                                                    seed=SEED, 
2313                                                    exclusion_radius_per_type = exclusion_radius_per_type
2314                                                    )
2315
2316        # Determine the concentrations of the various species in the reservoir and the equilibrium constants
2317        cH_res, cOH_res, cNa_res, cCl_res = self.determine_reservoir_concentrations(pH_res, c_salt_res, activity_coefficient)
2318        ionic_strength_res = 0.5*(cNa_res+cCl_res+cOH_res+cH_res)
2319        determined_activity_coefficient = activity_coefficient(ionic_strength_res)
2320        K_W = cH_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * cOH_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * determined_activity_coefficient
2321        K_NACL = cNa_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * cCl_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * determined_activity_coefficient
2322        K_HCL = cH_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * cCl_res.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * determined_activity_coefficient
2323
2324        proton_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==proton_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]
2325        hydroxide_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==hydroxide_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]     
2326        salt_cation_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==salt_cation_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]
2327        salt_anion_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==salt_anion_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]     
2328
2329        proton_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==proton_name].state_one.charge.values[0]
2330        hydroxide_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==hydroxide_name].state_one.charge.values[0]     
2331        salt_cation_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==salt_cation_name].state_one.charge.values[0]
2332        salt_anion_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==salt_anion_name].state_one.charge.values[0]     
2333
2334        if proton_charge <= 0:
2335            raise ValueError('ERROR proton charge must be positive, charge ', proton_charge)
2336        if salt_cation_charge <= 0:
2337            raise ValueError('ERROR salt cation charge must be positive, charge ', salt_cation_charge)
2338        if hydroxide_charge >= 0:
2339            raise ValueError('ERROR hydroxide charge must be negative, charge ', hydroxide_charge)
2340        if salt_anion_charge >= 0:
2341            raise ValueError('ERROR salt anion charge must be negative, charge ', salt_anion_charge)
2342
2343        # Grand-canonical coupling to the reservoir
2344        # 0 = H+ + OH-
2345        RE.add_reaction(
2346            gamma = K_W.magnitude,
2347            reactant_types = [],
2348            reactant_coefficients = [],
2349            product_types = [ proton_es_type, hydroxide_es_type ],
2350            product_coefficients = [ 1, 1 ],
2351            default_charges = {
2352                proton_es_type: proton_charge, 
2353                hydroxide_es_type: hydroxide_charge, 
2354            }
2355        )
2356
2357        # 0 = Na+ + Cl-
2358        RE.add_reaction(
2359            gamma = K_NACL.magnitude,
2360            reactant_types = [],
2361            reactant_coefficients = [],
2362            product_types = [ salt_cation_es_type, salt_anion_es_type ],
2363            product_coefficients = [ 1, 1 ],
2364            default_charges = {
2365                salt_cation_es_type: salt_cation_charge, 
2366                salt_anion_es_type: salt_anion_charge, 
2367            }
2368        )
2369
2370        # 0 = Na+ + OH-
2371        RE.add_reaction(
2372            gamma = (K_NACL * K_W / K_HCL).magnitude,
2373            reactant_types = [],
2374            reactant_coefficients = [],
2375            product_types = [ salt_cation_es_type, hydroxide_es_type ],
2376            product_coefficients = [ 1, 1 ],
2377            default_charges = {
2378                salt_cation_es_type: salt_cation_charge, 
2379                hydroxide_es_type: hydroxide_charge, 
2380            }
2381        )
2382
2383        # 0 = H+ + Cl-
2384        RE.add_reaction(
2385            gamma = K_HCL.magnitude,
2386            reactant_types = [],
2387            reactant_coefficients = [],
2388            product_types = [ proton_es_type, salt_anion_es_type ],
2389            product_coefficients = [ 1, 1 ],
2390            default_charges = {
2391                proton_es_type: proton_charge, 
2392                salt_anion_es_type: salt_anion_charge, 
2393            }
2394        )
2395
2396        # Annealing moves to ensure sufficient sampling
2397        # Cation annealing H+ = Na+
2398        RE.add_reaction(
2399            gamma = (K_NACL / K_HCL).magnitude,
2400            reactant_types = [proton_es_type],
2401            reactant_coefficients = [ 1 ],
2402            product_types = [ salt_cation_es_type ],
2403            product_coefficients = [ 1 ],
2404            default_charges = {
2405                proton_es_type: proton_charge, 
2406                salt_cation_es_type: salt_cation_charge, 
2407            }
2408        )
2409
2410        # Anion annealing OH- = Cl- 
2411        RE.add_reaction(
2412            gamma = (K_HCL / K_W).magnitude,
2413            reactant_types = [hydroxide_es_type],
2414            reactant_coefficients = [ 1 ],
2415            product_types = [ salt_anion_es_type ],
2416            product_coefficients = [ 1 ],
2417            default_charges = {
2418                hydroxide_es_type: hydroxide_charge, 
2419                salt_anion_es_type: salt_anion_charge, 
2420            }
2421        )
2422
2423        sucessful_reactions_labels=[]
2424        charge_map = self.get_charge_map()
2425        for name in pka_set.keys():
2426            if self.check_if_name_is_defined_in_df(name,pmb_type_to_be_defined='particle') is False :
2427                print('WARNING: the acid-base reaction of ' + name +' has not been set up because its espresso type is not defined in the type map.')
2428                continue
2429
2430            Ka = (10**-pka_set[name]['pka_value'] * self.units.mol/self.units.l).to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)')
2431
2432            state_one_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==name].state_one.es_type.values[0]
2433            state_two_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==name].state_two.es_type.values[0]
2434
2435            # Reaction in terms of proton: HA = A + H+
2436            RE.add_reaction(gamma=Ka.magnitude,
2437                            reactant_types=[state_one_type],
2438                            reactant_coefficients=[1],
2439                            product_types=[state_two_type, proton_es_type],
2440                            product_coefficients=[1, 1],
2441                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2442                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2443                            proton_es_type: proton_charge})
2444
2445            # Reaction in terms of salt cation: HA = A + Na+
2446            RE.add_reaction(gamma=(Ka * K_NACL / K_HCL).magnitude,
2447                            reactant_types=[state_one_type],
2448                            reactant_coefficients=[1],
2449                            product_types=[state_two_type, salt_cation_es_type],
2450                            product_coefficients=[1, 1],
2451                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2452                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2453                            salt_cation_es_type: salt_cation_charge})
2454
2455            # Reaction in terms of hydroxide: OH- + HA = A
2456            RE.add_reaction(gamma=(Ka / K_W).magnitude,
2457                            reactant_types=[state_one_type, hydroxide_es_type],
2458                            reactant_coefficients=[1, 1],
2459                            product_types=[state_two_type],
2460                            product_coefficients=[1],
2461                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2462                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2463                            hydroxide_es_type: hydroxide_charge})
2464
2465            # Reaction in terms of salt anion: Cl- + HA = A
2466            RE.add_reaction(gamma=(Ka / K_HCL).magnitude,
2467                            reactant_types=[state_one_type, salt_anion_es_type],
2468                            reactant_coefficients=[1, 1],
2469                            product_types=[state_two_type],
2470                            product_coefficients=[1],
2471                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2472                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2473                            salt_anion_es_type: salt_anion_charge})
2474
2475            sucessful_reactions_labels.append(name)
2476        return RE, sucessful_reactions_labels, ionic_strength_res

Sets up Acid/Base reactions for acidic/basic 'particles' defined in 'pmb.df', as well as a grand-canonical coupling to a reservoir of small ions. This implementation uses the original formulation of the grand-reaction method by Landsgesell et al. [1].

[1] Landsgesell, J., Hebbeker, P., Rud, O., Lunkad, R., Košovan, P., & Holm, C. (2020). Grand-reaction method for simulations of ionization equilibria coupled to ion partitioning. Macromolecules, 53(8), 3007-3020.

Arguments:
  • pH_res ('float): pH-value in the reservoir.
  • c_salt_res ('float'): Concentration of monovalent salt (e.g. NaCl) in the reservoir.
  • proton_name ('str'): Name of the proton (H+) particle.
  • hydroxide_name ('str'): Name of the hydroxide (OH-) particle.
  • salt_cation_name ('str'): Name of the salt cation (e.g. Na+) particle.
  • salt_anion_name ('str'): Name of the salt anion (e.g. Cl-) particle.
  • SEED ('int'): Seed for the random number generator.
  • activity_coefficient ('callable', optional): A function that calculates the activity coefficient of an ion pair as a function of the ionic strength.
  • exclusion_range(float, optional): For distances shorter than this value, no particles will be inserted.
  • pka_set(dict,optional): Desired pka_set, pka_set(dict): {"name" : {"pka_value": pka, "acidity": acidity}}. Defaults to None.
  • use_exclusion_radius_per_type(bool,optional): Controls if one exclusion_radius for each espresso_type is used. Defaults to False.
Returns:

RE (obj): Instance of a reaction_ensemble.ReactionEnsemble object from the espressomd library. sucessful_reactions_labels(lst): Labels of the reactions set up by pyMBE. ionic_strength_res ('float'): Ionic strength of the reservoir (useful for calculating partition coefficients).

def setup_grxmc_unified( self, pH_res, c_salt_res, cation_name, anion_name, SEED, activity_coefficient=None, exclusion_range=None, pka_set=None, use_exclusion_radius_per_type=False): 
2478    def setup_grxmc_unified (self, pH_res, c_salt_res, cation_name, anion_name, SEED, activity_coefficient=None, exclusion_range=None, pka_set=None, use_exclusion_radius_per_type = False):
2479        """
2480        Sets up Acid/Base reactions for acidic/basic 'particles' defined in 'pmb.df', as well as a grand-canonical coupling to a 
2481        reservoir of small ions. 
2482        This implementation uses the formulation of the grand-reaction method by Curk et al. [1], which relies on "unified" ion types X+ = {H+, Na+} and X- = {OH-, Cl-}. 
2483        A function that implements the original version of the grand-reaction method by Landsgesell et al. [2] is also available under the name 'setup_grxmc_reactions'.
2484
2485        [1] Curk, T., Yuan, J., & Luijten, E. (2022). Accelerated simulation method for charge regulation effects. The Journal of Chemical Physics, 156(4).
2486        [2] Landsgesell, J., Hebbeker, P., Rud, O., Lunkad, R., Košovan, P., & Holm, C. (2020). Grand-reaction method for simulations of ionization equilibria coupled to ion partitioning. Macromolecules, 53(8), 3007-3020.
2487
2488        Args:
2489            pH_res ('float'): pH-value in the reservoir.
2490            c_salt_res ('float'): Concentration of monovalent salt (e.g. NaCl) in the reservoir.
2491            cation_name ('str'): Name of the cationic particle.
2492            anion_name ('str'): Name of the anionic particle.
2493            SEED ('int'): Seed for the random number generator.
2494            activity_coefficient ('callable', optional): A function that calculates the activity coefficient of an ion pair as a function of the ionic strength.
2495            exclusion_range(`float`, optional): Below this value, no particles will be inserted.
2496            pka_set(`dict`,optional): Desired pka_set, pka_set(`dict`): {"name" : {"pka_value": pka, "acidity": acidity}}. Defaults to None.
2497            use_exclusion_radius_per_type(`bool`,optional): Controls if one exclusion_radius per each espresso_type. Defaults to `False`.
2498
2499        Returns:
2500            RE (`obj`): Instance of a reaction_ensemble.ReactionEnsemble object from the espressomd library.
2501            sucessful_reactions_labels(`lst`): Labels of the reactions set up by pyMBE.
2502            ionic_strength_res ('float'): Ionic strength of the reservoir (useful for calculating partition coefficients).
2503        """
2504        from espressomd import reaction_methods
2505        if exclusion_range is None:
2506            exclusion_range = max(self.get_radius_map().values())*2.0
2507        if pka_set is None:
2508            pka_set=self.get_pka_set()    
2509        self.check_pka_set(pka_set=pka_set)
2510        if use_exclusion_radius_per_type:
2511            exclusion_radius_per_type = self.get_radius_map()
2512        else:
2513            exclusion_radius_per_type = {}
2514        
2515        #If no function for the activity coefficient is provided, the ideal case is assumed.
2516        if activity_coefficient is None:
2517            activity_coefficient = lambda x: 1.0
2518        
2519        RE = reaction_methods.ReactionEnsemble(kT=self.kT.to('reduced_energy').magnitude,
2520                                                    exclusion_range=exclusion_range.magnitude, 
2521                                                    seed=SEED, 
2522                                                    exclusion_radius_per_type = exclusion_radius_per_type
2523                                                    )
2524
2525        # Determine the concentrations of the various species in the reservoir and the equilibrium constants
2526        cH_res, cOH_res, cNa_res, cCl_res = self.determine_reservoir_concentrations(pH_res, c_salt_res, activity_coefficient)
2527        ionic_strength_res = 0.5*(cNa_res+cCl_res+cOH_res+cH_res)
2528        determined_activity_coefficient = activity_coefficient(ionic_strength_res)
2529        a_hydrogen = (10 ** (-pH_res) * self.units.mol/self.units.l).to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)')
2530        a_cation = (cH_res+cNa_res).to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * self.np.sqrt(determined_activity_coefficient)
2531        a_anion = (cH_res+cNa_res).to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)') * self.np.sqrt(determined_activity_coefficient)
2532        K_XX = a_cation * a_anion
2533
2534        cation_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==cation_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]
2535        anion_es_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==anion_name].state_one.es_type.values[0]     
2536        cation_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==cation_name].state_one.charge.values[0]
2537        anion_charge = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==anion_name].state_one.charge.values[0]     
2538        if cation_charge <= 0:
2539            raise ValueError('ERROR cation charge must be positive, charge ', cation_charge)
2540        if anion_charge >= 0:
2541            raise ValueError('ERROR anion charge must be negative, charge ', anion_charge)
2542
2543        # Coupling to the reservoir: 0 = X+ + X-
2544        RE.add_reaction(
2545            gamma = K_XX.magnitude,
2546            reactant_types = [],
2547            reactant_coefficients = [],
2548            product_types = [ cation_es_type, anion_es_type ],
2549            product_coefficients = [ 1, 1 ],
2550            default_charges = {
2551                cation_es_type: cation_charge, 
2552                anion_es_type: anion_charge, 
2553            }
2554        )
2555
2556        sucessful_reactions_labels=[]
2557        charge_map = self.get_charge_map()
2558        for name in pka_set.keys():
2559            if self.check_if_name_is_defined_in_df(name,pmb_type_to_be_defined='particle') is False :
2560                print('WARNING: the acid-base reaction of ' + name +' has not been set up because its espresso type is not defined in sg.type_map')
2561                continue
2562
2563            Ka = 10**-pka_set[name]['pka_value'] * self.units.mol/self.units.l
2564            gamma_K_AX = Ka.to('1/(N_A * reduced_length**3)').magnitude * a_cation / a_hydrogen
2565
2566            state_one_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==name].state_one.es_type.values[0]
2567            state_two_type = self.df.loc[self.df['name']==name].state_two.es_type.values[0]
2568
2569            # Reaction in terms of small cation: HA = A + X+
2570            RE.add_reaction(gamma=gamma_K_AX.magnitude,
2571                            reactant_types=[state_one_type],
2572                            reactant_coefficients=[1],
2573                            product_types=[state_two_type, cation_es_type],
2574                            product_coefficients=[1, 1],
2575                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2576                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2577                            cation_es_type: cation_charge})
2578
2579            # Reaction in terms of small anion: X- + HA = A
2580            RE.add_reaction(gamma=gamma_K_AX.magnitude / K_XX.magnitude,
2581                            reactant_types=[state_one_type, anion_es_type],
2582                            reactant_coefficients=[1, 1],
2583                            product_types=[state_two_type],
2584                            product_coefficients=[1],
2585                            default_charges={state_one_type: charge_map[state_one_type],
2586                            state_two_type: charge_map[state_two_type],
2587                            anion_es_type: anion_charge})
2588
2589            sucessful_reactions_labels.append(name)
2590        return RE, sucessful_reactions_labels, ionic_strength_res

Sets up Acid/Base reactions for acidic/basic 'particles' defined in 'pmb.df', as well as a grand-canonical coupling to a reservoir of small ions. This implementation uses the formulation of the grand-reaction method by Curk et al. [1], which relies on "unified" ion types X+ = {H+, Na+} and X- = {OH-, Cl-}. A function that implements the original version of the grand-reaction method by Landsgesell et al. [2] is also available under the name 'setup_grxmc_reactions'.

[1] Curk, T., Yuan, J., & Luijten, E. (2022). Accelerated simulation method for charge regulation effects. The Journal of Chemical Physics, 156(4). [2] Landsgesell, J., Hebbeker, P., Rud, O., Lunkad, R., Košovan, P., & Holm, C. (2020). Grand-reaction method for simulations of ionization equilibria coupled to ion partitioning. Macromolecules, 53(8), 3007-3020.

Arguments:
  • pH_res ('float'): pH-value in the reservoir.
  • c_salt_res ('float'): Concentration of monovalent salt (e.g. NaCl) in the reservoir.
  • cation_name ('str'): Name of the cationic particle.
  • anion_name ('str'): Name of the anionic particle.
  • SEED ('int'): Seed for the random number generator.
  • activity_coefficient ('callable', optional): A function that calculates the activity coefficient of an ion pair as a function of the ionic strength.
  • exclusion_range(float, optional): Below this value, no particles will be inserted.
  • pka_set(dict,optional): Desired pka_set, pka_set(dict): {"name" : {"pka_value": pka, "acidity": acidity}}. Defaults to None.
  • use_exclusion_radius_per_type(bool,optional): Controls if one exclusion_radius per each espresso_type. Defaults to False.
Returns:

RE (obj): Instance of a reaction_ensemble.ReactionEnsemble object from the espressomd library. sucessful_reactions_labels(lst): Labels of the reactions set up by pyMBE. ionic_strength_res ('float'): Ionic strength of the reservoir (useful for calculating partition coefficients).

def setup_df(self): 
2592    def setup_df (self):
2593        """
2594        Sets up the pyMBE's dataframe `pymbe.df`.
2595
2596        Returns:
2597            columns_names(`obj`): pandas multiindex object with the column names of the pyMBE's dataframe
2598        """
2599
2600        columns_names = self.pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples ([
2601                        ('name',''),
2602                        ('pmb_type',''),
2603                        ('particle_id',''), 
2604                        ('particle_id2',''),
2605                        ('residue_id',''),
2606                        ('molecule_id',''),
2607                        ('acidity',''),
2608                        ('pka',''),
2609                        ('central_bead',''),
2610                        ('side_chains',''),
2611                        ('residue_list',''),
2612                        ('model',''),
2613                        ('diameter',''),
2614                        ('epsilon',''),
2615                        ('state_one','label'),
2616                        ('state_one','es_type'),
2617                        ('state_one','charge'),
2618                        ('state_two','label'),
2619                        ('state_two','es_type'),
2620                        ('state_two','charge'),
2621                        ('sequence',''),
2622                        ('bond_object',''),
2623                        ('parameters_of_the_potential','')
2624                        ])
2625
2626        self.df = self.pd.DataFrame (columns = columns_names)
2627      
2628        return columns_names

Sets up the pyMBE's dataframe pymbe.df.

Returns:

columns_names(obj): pandas multiindex object with the column names of the pyMBE's dataframe

def setup_lj_interactions( self, espresso_system, cutoff=None, shift='auto', combining_rule='Lorentz-Berthelot'): 
2630    def setup_lj_interactions (self, espresso_system, cutoff=None, shift='auto', combining_rule='Lorentz-Berthelot'):
2631        """
2632        Sets up the Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential between all pairs of particle types with values for `diameter` and `epsilon` stored in `pymbe.df`.
2633        Stores the parameters loaded into ESPResSo for each type pair in `pymbe.df`.
2634        Assumes that the LJ interactions between all particles will have the same `cutoff`, `shift` and `combining_rule`.
2635        Check the documentation of ESPResSo for more info about the potential https://espressomd.github.io/doc4.2.0/inter_non-bonded.html
2636
2637        Args:
2638            espresso_system(`obj`): Instance of a system object from the espressomd library.
2639            cutoff(`float`, optional): cut-off length of the LJ potential. Defaults to None.
2640            shift (`string`, optional): If set to `auto` shifts the potential to be continous at `cutoff`. Defaults to `auto`.
2641            combining_rule (`string`, optional): combining rule used to calculate `sigma` and `epsilon` for the potential betwen a pair of particles. Defaults to 'Lorentz-Berthelot'.
2642
2643        Note:
2644            If no `cutoff`  is given, its value is set to 2**(1./6.) in reduced_length units, corresponding to a purely steric potential.
2645
2646        Note:
2647            Currently, the only `combining_rule` supported is Lorentz-Berthelot.
2648        """
2649        from itertools import combinations_with_replacement
2650        sigma=1*self.units('reduced_length')
2651        implemented_combinatiorial_rules = ['Lorentz-Berthelot']
2652        compulsory_parameters_in_df = ['diameter','epsilon']
2653        if combining_rule not in implemented_combinatiorial_rules:
2654            raise ValueError('In the current version of pyMBE, the only combinatorial rules implemented are ', implemented_combinatiorial_rules)
2655        if cutoff is None:
2656            cutoff=2**(1./6.)*self.units('reduced_length')
2657        particles_types_with_LJ_parameters = []
2658        non_parametrized_labels= []
2659        for particle_type in self.get_type_map().values():
2660            check_list=[]
2661            for key in compulsory_parameters_in_df:
2662                value_in_df=self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=particle_type,
2663                                                        column_name=key)
2664                check_list.append(self.np.isnan(value_in_df))
2665            if any(check_list):
2666                non_parametrized_labels.append(self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=particle_type, 
2667                                                                            column_name='label'))
2668            else:
2669                particles_types_with_LJ_parameters.append(particle_type)
2670        for type_pair in combinations_with_replacement(particles_types_with_LJ_parameters, 2):
2671            diameter_list=[]
2672            epsilon_list=[]
2673            label_list=[]
2674            Non_interacting_pair=False
2675            # Search the LJ parameters of the type pair
2676            for ptype in type_pair:
2677                diameter=self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=ptype, column_name='diameter').to('reduced_length').magnitude
2678                label=self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=ptype, column_name='label')
2679                epsilon=self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=ptype, column_name='epsilon').to('reduced_energy').magnitude
2680                if diameter == 0:
2681                    Non_interacting_pair=True
2682                    break
2683                elif diameter < 0:
2684                    raise ValueError(f"Particle {label} has a negative diameter = {diameter}, check your pmb.df")
2685                else:   
2686                    label_list.append(label)
2687                    diameter_list.append(diameter)
2688                    epsilon_list.append(epsilon)
2689            # If the diameter of one of the particle types is 0, no LJ interaction is setup
2690            if Non_interacting_pair:
2691                pass
2692            if combining_rule == 'Lorentz-Berthelot':
2693                diameter_sum=self.np.sum(diameter_list)
2694                epsilon=self.np.sqrt(self.np.prod(epsilon_list))
2695                offset=diameter_sum/2.-sigma.to('reduced_length').magnitude
2696            espresso_system.non_bonded_inter[type_pair[0],type_pair[1]].lennard_jones.set_params(epsilon = epsilon, 
2697                                                                                    sigma = sigma.to('reduced_length').magnitude, 
2698                                                                                    cutoff = cutoff.to('reduced_length').magnitude,
2699                                                                                    offset = offset, 
2700                                                                                    shift = shift)                                                                                          
2701            index = len(self.df)
2702            self.df.at [index, 'name'] = f'LJ: {label_list[0]}-{label_list[1]}'
2703            lj_params=espresso_system.non_bonded_inter[type_pair[0], type_pair[1]].lennard_jones.get_params()
2704            self.add_value_to_df(index=index,
2705                                key=('pmb_type',''),
2706                                new_value='LennardJones')
2707            self.add_value_to_df(index=index,
2708                                key=('parameters_of_the_potential',''),
2709                                new_value=self.json.dumps(lj_params))                
2710        if non_parametrized_labels:
2711            print(f'WARNING: No LJ interaction has been added in ESPResSo for particles with labels: {non_parametrized_labels}. Please, check your pmb.df to ensure if this is your desired setup.')
2712        return

Sets up the Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential between all pairs of particle types with values for diameter and epsilon stored in pymbe.df. Stores the parameters loaded into ESPResSo for each type pair in pymbe.df. Assumes that the LJ interactions between all particles will have the same cutoff, shift and combining_rule. Check the documentation of ESPResSo for more info about the potential https://espressomd.github.io/doc4.2.0/inter_non-bonded.html

Arguments:
  • espresso_system(obj): Instance of a system object from the espressomd library.
  • cutoff(float, optional): cut-off length of the LJ potential. Defaults to None.
  • shift (string, optional): If set to auto shifts the potential to be continous at cutoff. Defaults to auto.
  • combining_rule (string, optional): combining rule used to calculate sigma and epsilon for the potential betwen a pair of particles. Defaults to 'Lorentz-Berthelot'.
Note:

If no cutoff is given, its value is set to 2**(1./6.) in reduced_length units, corresponding to a purely steric potential.

Note:

Currently, the only combining_rule supported is Lorentz-Berthelot.

def setup_particle_diameter(self, topology_dict): 
2714    def setup_particle_diameter(self, topology_dict):
2715        '''
2716        Sets up the diameter of the particles in `positions`.
2717
2718        Args:
2719            topology_dict(`dict`): {'initial_pos': coords_list, 'chain_id': id, 'diameter': diameter_value}
2720        '''
2721        for residue in topology_dict.keys():
2722            residue_name = self.re.split(r'\d+', residue)[0]
2723            residue_number = self.re.split(r'(\d+)', residue)[1]
2724            residue_diameter  = topology_dict[residue]['diameter']
2725            diameter = residue_diameter*self.units.nm
2726            index = self.df[(self.df['residue_id']==residue_number) & (self.df['name']==residue_name) ].index.values[0]
2727
2728            self.add_value_to_df(key= ('diameter',''),
2729                        index=int (index),
2730                        new_value=diameter)
2731            
2732        return

Sets up the diameter of the particles in positions.

Arguments:
  • topology_dict(dict): {'initial_pos': coords_list, 'chain_id': id, 'diameter': diameter_value}
def write_output_vtf_file(self, espresso_system, filename): 
2734    def write_output_vtf_file(self, espresso_system, filename):
2735        '''
2736        Writes a snapshot of `espresso_system` on the vtf file `filename`.
2737
2738        Args:
2739            espresso_system(`obj`): Instance of a system object from the espressomd library.
2740            filename(`str`): Path to the vtf file.
2741
2742        '''
2743        box = espresso_system.box_l[0]
2744        with open(filename, mode='w+t') as coordinates:
2745            coordinates.write (f'unitcell {box} {box} {box} \n')
2746            for particle in espresso_system.part: 
2747                type_label = self.find_value_from_es_type(es_type=particle.type, column_name='label')
2748                coordinates.write (f'atom {particle.id} radius 1 name {type_label} type {type_label}\n' )
2749            coordinates.write (f'timestep indexed\n')
2750            for particle in espresso_system.part:
2751                coordinates.write (f'{particle.id} \t {particle.pos[0]} \t {particle.pos[1]} \t {particle.pos[2]}\n')
2752        return

Writes a snapshot of espresso_system on the vtf file filename.

Arguments:
  • espresso_system(obj): Instance of a system object from the espressomd library.
  • filename(str): Path to the vtf file.
